```{r setup, include=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(tidyverse)
library(reshape2)
library(missForest)
library(randomForest)
library(caret)
library(e1071)
library(caTools)
library(mltools)
library(xgboost)
library(viridis) 
```

The dataset chosen was the Car Insurance Claim dataset.

```{r}
carDf <- read.csv("Car_Insurance_Claim.csv")
```

```{r}
head(carDf,5)
```

Before changing the categorical column to its labels, i will save some labels.

```{r}
labelDRIVING_EXPERIENCE <- unique(carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE)
labelVEHICLE_YEAR <- unique(carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR)
```

We will change the categorical values into multiple category values. We need to change the type of the column to a numerical one so we can plot a correlation matrix.

```{r}
sapply(carDf, class)
```

```{r}
carDf %>% 
  select(DRIVING_EXPERIENCE) %>% 
  group_by(DRIVING_EXPERIENCE) %>% 
  summarise(count = n(),
            .groups = 'drop') %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = factor(DRIVING_EXPERIENCE), y = count, fill = DRIVING_EXPERIENCE)) +
  geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat="identity") +
  scale_x_discrete(breaks = c(0, 1), labels = c("FALSE","TRUE")) +
  labs(title = "Number of violations for each category", x = "", y = "Amount") +
  theme_classic()
```


```{r}
carDf <- carDf %>% 
    mutate(DRIVING_EXPERIENCE = case_when(DRIVING_EXPERIENCE == "20-29y" ~ "20y+",
                                          DRIVING_EXPERIENCE == "30y+" ~ "20y+",
                                          TRUE ~ DRIVING_EXPERIENCE))
```


```{r}
carDf$AGE <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$AGE,levels = c("16-25", "26-39", "40-64", "65+")))

carDf$GENDER <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$GENDER,labels = c("male", "female")))

carDf$RACE <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$RACE,labels = c("minority", "majority")))

carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE,labels = c("0-9y", "10-19y", "20y+")))

carDf$EDUCATION <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$EDUCATION,labels = c("none", "high school", "university")))

carDf$INCOME <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$INCOME,labels = c("poverty", "working class", "middle class", "upper class")))

carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR,labels = c("before 2015", "after 2015")))

carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE <- as.numeric(factor(carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE,labels = c("sedan","sports_car")))
```

We summarise the data set to have an overview of each column.

```{r}
summary(carDf)
```

```{r}
sapply(carDf, typeof)
```


We will save the correlation values between columns into a dataframe. We removed ID from the correlation plot it was white in almost every tile.

```{r}
corrDf <- carDf %>% 
  select(AGE, GENDER, RACE, DRIVING_EXPERIENCE, EDUCATION, INCOME,
         CREDIT_SCORE, VEHICLE_OWNERSHIP, VEHICLE_TYPE, VEHICLE_YEAR, MARRIED, CHILDREN, 
         POSTAL_CODE, ANNUAL_MILEAGE, SPEEDING_VIOLATIONS, DUIS, PAST_ACCIDENTS,
         OUTCOME) %>% 
  cor(use="pairwise.complete.obs") %>% 
  round(3)
```

```{r}
corrDf %>% 
  melt() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=Var1, y=Var2, fill=value)) + 
  geom_tile(color = "white") +
  scale_fill_gradient2(low = "blue", high = "red", mid = "white", midpoint = 0, 
                       limit = c(-1,1), space = "Lab", name="Pearson\nCorrelation") +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 1, hjust = 1)) +
  coord_fixed() + 
  scale_size(range = c(0.2, 5)) +
  geom_text(aes(Var2, Var1, label = value), color = "black", size = 1.5) +
  labs(title = "Correlation plot between each column") +
  theme(axis.title.x = element_blank(),
        axis.title.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
        panel.border = element_blank(),
        panel.background = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        legend.justification = c(1, 0),
        legend.position = "right")
```

First, let us see the most correlated features with the OUTCOME column.

```{r}
corrDf %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  select(OUTCOME) %>% 
  mutate(posOUTCOME = case_when(OUTCOME < 0 ~ abs(OUTCOME),
                               OUTCOME >= 0  ~ OUTCOME))  %>% 
  arrange(desc(posOUTCOME)) %>% 
  select(OUTCOME)
```

We can see that the 5 columns most correlated to the column OUTCOME are:
- DRIVING_EXPERIENCE
- VEHICLE_OWNERSHIP
- CREDIT_SCORE
- PAST_ACCIDENTS
- VEHICLE_YEAR

And the 5 columns least correlated to the column OUTCOME are:
- RACE
- AGE
- EDUCATION
- POSTAL_CODE
- GENDER

Now we have seen that there are 2 column with some a lot of NA values. Those columns are the CREDIT_SCORE and the ANNUAL_MILEAGE. One question we might ask is if it is possible to delete those columns. However, from the previous table we could see there is some correlation from the target and those 2 columns. So the following will be a method how to deal and solve the NA issue. 

```{r}
carDf$AGE <- factor(carDf$AGE)
carDf$GENDER <- factor(carDf$GENDER)
carDf$RACE <- factor(carDf$RACE)
carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE <- factor(carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE)
carDf$EDUCATION <- factor(carDf$EDUCATION)
carDf$INCOME <- factor(carDf$INCOME)
carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR <- factor(carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR)
carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE <- factor(carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE)
carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE <- factor(carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE)
```

```{r}
carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE <- as.numeric(carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE)
f <- function(x) x + 1
carDf <- cbind(carDf[c(1:13, 15:19)], apply(carDf[14],2, f))
carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE <- factor(carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE)
```

```{r}
oldANNUAL <- as.numeric(carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE)
oldCREDIT <- carDf$CREDIT_SCORE
```

```{r}
carDf <- carDf %>% 
  select(AGE, GENDER, RACE, DRIVING_EXPERIENCE, EDUCATION, INCOME,
         CREDIT_SCORE, VEHICLE_OWNERSHIP, VEHICLE_TYPE, VEHICLE_YEAR, MARRIED, CHILDREN, 
         POSTAL_CODE, ANNUAL_MILEAGE, SPEEDING_VIOLATIONS, DUIS, PAST_ACCIDENTS,
         OUTCOME)
```

```{r}
carDfMissF <- missForest(carDf)
```

```{r}
carDfMissF$OOBerror
```

```{r}
carDfMissF$ximp %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_density(aes(x = CREDIT_SCORE)) +
  geom_density(aes(x = oldCREDIT), color="blue", linetype="dashed", na.rm = TRUE) +
  labs(title = "People claiming a loan vs people not claiming a loan", x = "", y = "Amount")
```

```{r}
carDfMissF$ximp$ANNUAL_MILEAGE <- as.numeric(carDfMissF$ximp$ANNUAL_MILEAGE)

carDfMissF$ximp %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_density(aes(x = ANNUAL_MILEAGE)) +
  geom_density(aes(x = oldANNUAL), color="blue", linetype="dashed", na.rm = TRUE) +
  labs(title = "People claiming a loan vs people not claiming a loan", x = "ANNUAL_MILEAGE in (km) - 1 km", y = "Amount")
```

Since we decided to accept the filled NA values by the missForest algorithm, we will save them in the original data set carDf.

```{r}
carDf <- carDfMissF$ximp
rm(carDfMissF)
```

```{r}
carDf<- carDf %>% 
  mutate(VEHICLE_TYPE = case_when(VEHICLE_TYPE == 1 ~ 'sedan',
                                  VEHICLE_TYPE == 2 ~ 'sport_car'))
```

```{r}
carDf$AGE <- as.numeric(carDf$AGE)

carDf$GENDER <- as.numeric(carDf$GENDER)

carDf$RACE <- as.numeric(carDf$RACE)

carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE <- as.numeric(carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE)

carDf$EDUCATION <- as.numeric(carDf$EDUCATION)

carDf$INCOME <- as.numeric(carDf$INCOME)

carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR <- as.numeric(carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR)
```

```{r}
sapply(carDf, class)
```


```{r}
carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE <- factor(carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE)
dummy <- dummyVars(" ~ .", data=carDf)
carDf <- data.frame(predict(dummy, newdata=carDf))

rm(dummy)
```

Now we have filled the NA's values cells, we can study the data a little more. We will do some plots to visualize what we are working with.

We need to solve the problem of data set being imbalanced. We will need to handle this problem later.

```{r}
carDf$AGE <- factor(carDf$AGE)
carDf$GENDER <- factor(carDf$GENDER)
carDf$RACE <- factor(carDf$RACE)
carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE <- factor(carDf$DRIVING_EXPERIENCE)
carDf$EDUCATION <- factor(carDf$EDUCATION)
carDf$INCOME <- factor(carDf$INCOME)
carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR <- factor(carDf$VEHICLE_YEAR)
carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE.sedan <- factor(carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE.sedan)
carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE.sport_car <- factor(carDf$VEHICLE_TYPE.sport_car)
carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE <- factor(carDf$ANNUAL_MILEAGE)
carDf$OUTCOME <- factor(carDf$OUTCOME)
```

```{r}
carDf %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = factor(OUTCOME))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  scale_x_discrete(breaks = c("0","1")) +
  labs(title = "People claiming a loan vs people not claiming a loan", x = "", y = "Amount")
```

```{r}
normalizedVector <- carDf %>% 
  select(OUTCOME) %>% 
  group_by(OUTCOME) %>% 
  summarise(count = n(),
            .groups = 'drop') %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  select(count)
```



# DRIVING_EXPERIENCE

```{r}
carDf %>% 
  select(OUTCOME, DRIVING_EXPERIENCE) %>% 
  group_by(OUTCOME, DRIVING_EXPERIENCE) %>% 
  summarise(count = n(),
            .groups = 'drop') %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  mutate(normalizedCount = case_when(OUTCOME == 0 ~ (count / normalizedVector[1, ] * 100), 
                                   TRUE ~ (count/ normalizedVector[2, ] * 100))) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = factor(OUTCOME), y = normalizedCount, fill = DRIVING_EXPERIENCE)) +
  geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat="identity") +
  scale_x_discrete(breaks = c(0, 1), labels = c("FALSE","TRUE")) +
  scale_fill_viridis(discrete = TRUE, alpha = 0.8, labels = c("0 - 9", "10 - 19", "20 +"), name = "Years of driving experience") +
  labs(title = "Amount of each driving experience", x = "Claimed the loan", y = "Amount") +
  theme_classic()
```

# PAST_ACCIDENTS

Here we study the distributions of the violations columns: SPEEDING_VIOLATIONS, DUIS, PAST_ACCIDENTS. We can see they follow a power law distribution.

```{r}
carDf %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = SPEEDING_VIOLATIONS)) +
    geom_bar(alpha = 0.8)

carDf %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = DUIS)) +
    geom_bar(alpha = 0.8)

carDf %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = PAST_ACCIDENTS)) +
    geom_bar(alpha = 0.8)
```

Now let us how it

```{r}
carDf %>% 
  select(OUTCOME, SPEEDING_VIOLATIONS, DUIS, PAST_ACCIDENTS) %>% 
  group_by(OUTCOME) %>% 
  summarise(across(everything(), sum),
            .groups = 'drop')  %>%
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  pivot_longer(!OUTCOME, names_to = "categories", values_to = "count") %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = factor(OUTCOME), y = count, fill = categories)) +
  geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat="identity") +
  scale_x_discrete(breaks = c(0, 1), labels = c("FALSE","TRUE")) +
  scale_fill_discrete(labels = c("Drink and driving", "Accidents", "Speeding"), name = "Violations") +
  labs(title = "Number of violations for each category", x = "", y = "Amount")
```

# Balance the dataset

Before we talk about balancing the dataset, we will first split the data into training and testing. Later we will balance the training data.


```{r}
set.seed(42)

sample <- sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), nrow(carDf), replace=TRUE, prob=c(0.8,0.2))
train <- carDf[sample, ]
test <- carDf[!sample, ]

rm(sample)
```

```{r}
train %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = factor(OUTCOME))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  scale_x_discrete(breaks = c("0","1")) +
  labs(title = "People claiming a loan vs people not claiming a loan", x = "", y = "Amount")
```



```{r}
set.seed(9560)

up_train <- upSample(x = train[, - 19], y = train$OUTCOME)                         
table(up_train$Class) 
```

```{r}
train <- up_train
rm(up_train)
```

```{r}
train %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = factor(Class))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  scale_x_discrete(breaks = c("0","1")) +
  labs(title = "People claiming a loan vs people not claiming a loan", x = "", y = "Amount")
```

```{r}
sapply(carDf, class)
```


# Models

## Random Forest

```{r}
rf <- randomForest(Class ~ ., data=train, proximity=TRUE) 
print(rf)
```

```{r}
p1 <- predict(rf, train)
confusionMatrix(p1, train$Class, positive = "1")
```

```{r}
p2 <- predict(rf, test)
confusionMatrix(p2, test$OUTCOME, positive = "1")
```

## XGBoost

```{r}
dtrain <- xgb.DMatrix(data = as.matrix(train[, - 19]), label=train$Class)
bst <- xgb.train(data=dtrain, max.depth=2, 
                 eta=1, nthread = 2, nrounds=2, watchlist=watchlist, objective = "binary:logistic")
```

```{r}

```


```{r}
p3 <- predict(model_xgb, test)
confusionMatrix(p3, test$OUTCOME, positive = "1")
```


```{r}
p2 <- predict(xgboost_model, xgboost_train)
```




## Support Vector Machine

```{r}
svm_model <- svm(as.factor(Class) ~ ., data=train, kernel = "radial", cost = 5)
print(svm_model)
```

```{r}
p1 <- predict(svm_model, train)
confusionMatrix(p1, train$Class, positive = "1")
```

```{r}
p2 <- predict(svm_model, test)
confusionMatrix(p2, test$OUTCOME, positive = "1")
```

## Naïve Bayes

```{r}
nBayes <- naiveBayes(as.factor(Class) ~ ., data=train)
print(nBayes)
```

```{r}
p1 <- predict(nBayes, train)
confusionMatrix(p1, train$Class, positive = "1")
```

```{r}
p2 <- predict(nBayes, test)
confusionMatrix(p2, test$OUTCOME, positive = "1")
```


As we can see from the accuracy, we will rank the best model to worst models.
1. Random Forest
2. Support Vector Machine
3. Naïve Bayes

So we decided to continue with the random forest model.

# Cross-validation


```{r}
repeat_cv <- trainControl(method='repeatedcv', number=10, repeats=3)

forest <- train(
        as.factor(Class)~., 
        data=train, 
        method='rf', 
        trControl=repeat_cv,
        metric='Accuracy')
```

```{r}
print(forest)
```

```{r}
sapply(test, class)
```

```{r}
sapply(train, class)
```



```{r}
p4 <- predict(forest, test)
confusionMatrix(p4, test$OUTCOME, positive = "1")
```
